title: Do I have to file a probate when my mothers estate is insoluble?
question: I know I'm supposed to file if her assets are over $100,000. However she owes a mortgage of $97,000, medical of 6,000 (also Medi-cal is requesting 12,500back), 10,000 in credit card debt, and other small debt. The estate if we're are lucky is worth maybe $130,000. And I haven't made a house payment since she died 2 months Oct will be 3. So would I get in trouble if I didn't file probate and just walk?!
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Wills and estates,Estates,Taxes and estate planning,Wills,Probate,Tax law
answers:
I've just been through an insolvent estate situation. If your name is not on the mortgage and you are not liable on the credit cards, I see absolutely no advantage to you in beginning a probate proceeding ... you'll just be throwing good money after bad.

The information you obtain at this site is not, nor is it intended to be, legal advice. You should consult an attorney for individual advice regarding your own situation.

Particularly if there is no will and you are not named as personal representative (you don't say, but I assume you would have mentioned a will if there was one) you have no obligation to begin probate. There are possible situations where you might even though the estate appears insolvent at first blush.

It would be well worth the effort and cost to briefly consult with a local probate attorney to determine if there are aspects of this that would change the assumptions here, and might make probate make sense.

You should also bear in mind, that if you didn't guarantee any of the debts and your name is not on the assets or debts, you are under no obligation to pay your mother's debts, but again, you should bring all the facts to a local attorney to insure you don't do something that will cause problems for you later.

Generally, you are not required to probate a will. If the estate's liabilities exceed the assets, then by all means you should not file. Also, do not pay the mortgage if the property was owned only by your mom and you did not personally guarantee the loan.
